tossups.question: The story of a mother and child who visited this sculpture every day is recounted by the male protagonist of Abbas Kiarostami’s Certified Copy. Agostino di Duccio was given this sculpture’s original commission, but he was replaced by Antonio Rossellino. In 2014, a team of geophysicists modelled the catastrophic failure of this sculpture’s (*) ankles. A replica of this sculpture stands outside the Palazzo Vecchio at its original location in the Piazza della Signoria. This statue is now located in the Galleria dell’Accademia in Florence. For 10 points, name this Michelangelo sculpture that depicts the title sling-holding biblical figure prior to his battle with Goliath.
tossups.answer: Michelangelo's David

tossups.question: Phase changes in one type of these substances formed from chalcogens serves the basis of non-volatile memory. Zachariasen developed a series of purely topological rules for how the polyhedral subunits of these isotropic substances form random networks. These substances have unit cells of infinite size due to their lack of long-range order. A rapid increase in viscosity and accompanying increase in Young’s modulus marks a namesake (*) phase transition in these substances. Adding boron trioxide to these substances suppresses their thermal expansion and their melting point is lowered by adding soda lime. For 10 points, name these amorphous substances typically made from silicon dioxide which are used to make flasks and other labwares.
tossups.answer: glasses [accept chalcogenide glasses; accept borosilicate or soda-lime glass; prompt on network solids, amorphous solids, or non-crystalline solids]

tossups.question: At a dinner party hosted by this man, one of his guests identifies the true American genius as the man who can write a perfect Prince Albert Tobacco ad. This man lives in a city described as “the Zip City – Zeal, Zest and Zowie” and mingles with the newspaper lyricist Chum Frink. Following a well-received speech given in Monarch where he defends his profession, this man campaigns for Prout against the more radical politician Seneca Doane. He eventually joins the (*) Good Citizen’s League and renounces his bohemian ways after his wife Myra becomes sick at the end of the novel. This man begins his namesake novel as a tireless booster of his hometown of Zenith. For 10 points, name this title real estate agent of a Sinclair Lewis novel.
tossups.answer: George F. Babbitt [or George F. Babbitt]

tossups.question: Engel curves belong to a set of curves that link all bundles consumed when this variable changes. The exogenous portion of this quantity is represented by the height of the kink point for a kinked constraint curve. This quantity is the constraint according to which the (emphasize) Marshallian demand function is calculated. In an effect named for this quantity, demand for inferior goods decreases as this quantity increases. A rightward parallel shift of the (*) budget constraint is created by a positive effect named for this quantity; that effect is contrasted with the usually negative substitution effect. For 10 points, multiplying wages by hours worked gives what quantity, the amount of money a person receives within a given period?
tossups.answer: income [accept income-consumption curves; accept wealth; accept budget before mentioned; accept wages before mentioned]

tossups.question: This Prime Minister’s admiral Dudley Pound opposed the flotilla reinforcements recommended by Operation Catherine. Anthony Eden was Dominions Secretary to this Prime Minister until he was heckled by chants of “they missed the bus” in Parliament. This Prime Minister initiated Plan Z after another leader issued the Godesberg ultimatum to Edvard Beneš. Leo Amery quoted Oliver Cromwell in attacking this man’s foreign policy by saying “in the name of God, go!” This man waved a paper at Heston (*) Aerodrome before issuing his most famous proclamation. This man resigned shortly after the Norway Debate. For 10 points, name this British Prime Minister who declared “peace for our time” with the Munich Agreement and was succeeded by Winston Churchill.
tossups.answer: Neville Chamberlain [or Arthur Neville Chamberlain]

tossups.question: This composer once remarked that he wished to replace an adjective in the title of one of his pieces with the word “humanity.” That work by this composer omits the violins from its first movement, in which a soprano sings a rising F, A, B-flat motif. This composer set Goethe verses to music in his Alto Rhapsody, which shares compositional similarities with and was written alongside a larger seven-movement work for chorus and orchestra. That piece by this composer both opens and ends with refrains of the word (*) “Selig” (“ZAY-lick”), or “Blessed,” as the piece quotes the Beatitudes. He commemorated his mother with a requiem that may have also been inspired by the death of his friend Robert Schumann. For 10 points, name this composer of A German Requiem.
tossups.answer: Johannes Brahms

tossups.question: Some satirical novels written in this language follow the “Comical History” of “States and Empires” on the sun and moon. The Extraordinary Voyages series includes a novel in this language about the Baltimore Gun Club, who construct a giant cannon. A novel in this language begins with a German professor translating runes found in an Icelandic saga. This language was used to write Micromégas and (*) From the Earth to the Moon. The protagonist of a novel in this language encounters dinosaurs, giant mushrooms, and petrified trees with his nephew before emerging to the Earth's surface via Mt. Stromboli. For 10 points, what language was used to write Journey to the Center of the Earth by Jules Verne?
tossups.answer: French [or langue française]

tossups.question: Three of Andre Weil’s (“vay’s”) conjectures about generating functions named for this letter were solved by Alexander Grothendieck (“GRO-tun-deek”), who failed to show that the magnitude of alpha was bounded. Though not pi, a function named for this letter determines the terms in a formula that provides an explicit means of calculating the number of primes less than x. When the input is one, the best-known function named for this letter reduces to the (*) harmonic series. A commonly-assumed hypothesis states that all the non-trivial zeros of a function named for this letter are either negative even integers or have real part one-half. A class of functions that sum up one over n to the s are named for, for 10 points, what Greek letter that names a function of Riemann?
tossups.answer: zeta [accept Riemann zeta function, zeta functions, or local zeta functions; prompt on L-functions]

tossups.question: This text’s eleventh book concludes that time is a “distention” of memory, and that God existed “before” time. The author of this book recollects learning words by watching adults move towards an object while saying its name in an account of language-learning that Wittgenstein challenges at the start of his Philosophical Investigations. This book’s protagonist waits nine years to have his questions answered by (*) Bishop Faustus. Earlier in this book, the protagonist is peer-pressured into stealing fruit from a pear tree. In Ostia, its protagonist hears a child say “tolle, lege,” (“TOLL-ay, LEG-ay”) or “take up and read,” so he reads Romans 13 and converts to Christianity. For 10 points, name this spiritual autobiography of Augustine of Hippo.
tossups.answer: The Confessions of Saint Augustine [or Confessiones; or Confessions in Thirteen Books; or Saint Augustine’s Confessions]

tossups.question: Fifteen members of this country’s army took acting lessons to pose as NGO workers for Operation Jaque, which captured a man nicknamed “Eyeglasses.” During the same era, as many as 5,000 innocent “false positives” were killed by this country’s military, which also runs its police. This country’s 19th of April Movement or M-19 supported former dictator Gustavo Rojas Pinilla. A man elected to Congress in this country served a prison sentence in the luxurious La (*) Catedral and owned the Hacienda Nápoles, the source of invasive hippos. In the 1980s, the drug trade in this country was controlled by “The King of Cocaine,” Pablo Escobar of the Medellin Cartel. For 10 points, name this country where anti-FARC rallies have been held in Bogota.
tossups.answer: Colombia [or Republic of Colombia]

tossups.question: A discourse titled after this stuff declares that this stuff takes the form of lust, hate, delusion, and various forms of sorrow, before listing the ways a noble follower will find estrangement. A common motif of Tibetan Buddhist mandalas is an outer ring of stylized scrollwork representing this stuff. In the Karandavyuha Sutra, the preaching of the dharma by Avalokiteśvara transforms a pool of this stuff in (*) Avici into a refreshing lotus pond. The Buddha delivered a sermon titled after this stuff after converting a group of brahmins who previously performed the agnihotra sacrifice to Agni, the Vedic god of this stuff. For 10 points, name this stuff, which titles a sermon from the Buddha in which he declared that "all is burning."
tossups.answer: fire [or flame; or aggi or agni; accept burning before it is read; accept Fire Sermon]

tossups.question: Sandwiches first created in this city include the plantain-based Jibarito and the massive "Gym Shoe." This city's Harold Ramis Film School emerged from an institution that trained actors such as Halle Berry and Chris Farley. The online music magazine Pitchfork is headquartered in this city. It's not Toronto or Los Angeles, but comedians such as Steve Carell trained at The (*) Second City improv in this city. This city’s Grant Park is the site of the Lollapalooza music festival. The Goodman Theatre is the oldest non-profit theater in this city's Loop district, also home to a sculpture in Millennium Park nicknamed "The Bean." For 10 points, name this "Windy City," the most populous in Illinois.
tossups.answer: Chicago, Illinois

tossups.question: This author created a character who suffers endlessly in the Pond of Blood and the Mountain of Needles. In a story by this author, news that the title creature will "ascend to heaven" spreads after a priest puts up a false sign. One of this author's characters boasts that nobody ever "clashed swords with [him] twenty strokes" and is arrested carrying a quiver and an unknown number of arrows. This author wrote an "Old Potter's Tale" titled "Dragon." In stories by this author, the thief Kandata fails to escape (*) hell by climbing the title object, and a murder is recounted by a woodcutter, a bandit, and a ghost. "The Spider's Thread" and "In a Grove" are short stories by, for 10 points, which Japanese author of "Rashomon?"
tossups.answer: Ryunosuke Akutagawa [or Akutagawa Ryunosuke; or Chōkōdō Shujin]

tossups.question: These people's cowboy culture extends back to Ahaya the Cowkeeper, and they now manage the fifth-largest cattle operation in the US. One leader of these people had his head posthumously severed by Army surgeon Frederick Weedon so phrenologist Lorenzo Fowler could examine it. During one conflict, these people moved from living in log cabins to thatched-roof structures called chickees. General Thomas Jesup imprisoned a leader of this people during peace negotiations in 1837 in a conflict partially sparked by enslaved people fleeing to become (*) "Black" members of this people. In this people's second war with the US, they were led by Osceola. For 10 points, name this Native American tribe which lost control of Florida following wars with the US.
tossups.answer: Seminoles [accept Black Seminoles; accept Alachua]

tossups.question: Bisphenol A binds to receptors for this compound, as do isoflavones found in red clover and soy. SERMs such as tamoxifen target this hormone's receptor. This hormone is brought down to 18 carbons from its precursor’s 27 by the loss of a side-chain, the removal of acetone by cytochrome P450 17A1, and the elimination of a methyl by (*) aromatase. The three major forms of this hormone are named for the numbers of hydroxyl groups they contain. Triple negative breast cancers are harder to treat hormonally because they do not express receptors for HER2 (“her-two”), progesterone or this hormone. A rise in the levels of this hormone causes a surge of luteinizing hormone and triggers ovulation. For 10 points, name this primary female sex hormone.
tossups.answer: estrogens [accept estrone, estradiol, or estriol]

tossups.question: An ally of this group created a magic herb that would have rendered them invincible, but their opponent commanded the Sun and Moon not to shine to stop them. Two of these beings, Agrius and Thoon, were slain during one event by three figures wielding bronze clubs. Alcyoneus, a member of this group, was immortal as long as he stood on his native land. Alcyoneus was killed using a tactic that had been shown effective against another member of this group, (*) Antaeus. Heracles was recruited to fight this group after a prophecy that the help of a mortal was necessary to defeat them. For 10 points, name these children of Gaia who launched the last major assault against the Olympians, and were notable for being extremely large.
tossups.answer: the Giants [or the Gigantes]

tossups.question: In the 10th century, Ibn Washiyya al-Nabati wrote an important text on this system titled Kitab Shauq al-Mustaham. Modern scholars studying this system often consult a list compiled by Sir Alan Gardiner in 1927. The physicist Thomas Young confirmed some insights about this system by William John Bankes from an object from Philae. Pierre-François Bouchard, a (*) Napoleonic officer, found an object that proved crucial to Jean-François Champollion’s successful analysis of this system. Key insights into this system followed the discovery of an object that contained inscriptions written in Ancient Greek and Demotic. For 10 points, name this ancient Egyptian writing system decoded after the discovery of the Rosetta Stone.
tossups.answer: Egyptian hieroglyphics [accept the ancient Egyptian writing system before mentioned; accept Egyptian demotic before mentioned]

tossups.question: This quantity’s operator is modified by the creation and annihilation operators. A power series expansion of this quantity over volume is set equal to the compressibility factor to generate the virial equation of state. This property, volume, and temperature define the canonical ensemble. This quantity’s factorial is in the denominator of the partition function for a system of indistinguishable particles. This quantity’s conjugate variable is the (*) chemical potential, which is defined as the change in energy of a system with respect to this quantity. When writing the ideal gas law in terms of Boltzmann’s constant, this quantity replaces the moles. For 10 points, give this quantity equal to the product of the number of moles and Avogadro’s number.
tossups.answer: particle number [accept equivalents such as number of particles; accept atoms or molecules in place of particle; prompt on N; prompt on number]

tossups.question: This country's congress meets in a complex consisting of two vertical towers that are flanked by two white hemispheres, one facing up and the other down. A cathedral in this country is built out of sixteen concrete columns that are bent to form a glass-enclosed hyperboloid. The Monumental Axis is the focal point of the Roberto Marx designed layout of a city in this country. That (*) airport-shaped capital city was built on the orders of its President Juscelino Kubitschek (“zhoo-say-LEE-noo koo-bee-CHEK”). This country's Corcovado is home to an enormous Paul Landowski-sculpted, concrete and soapstone monument of Christ. For 10 points, name this country in which Lucio Costa, Joaquim Cardozo, and Oscar Niemeyer designed its capital of Brasilia.
tossups.answer: Brazil [or Federative Republic of Brazil; or República Federativa do Brasil]

tossups.question: A poem by this author is quoted by Dr. Vivian Bearing as she realizes she is dying of ovarian cancer in Margaret Edson's play Wit. This poet of "This is my play's last scene" wrote the poem "Since she whom I loved hath paid her last debt," lamenting the death of his wife Ann More. This poet stated that "poppy or charms can make us sleep as well" before asking one figure why they (*) "swell'st." Izaak Walton's biography of this poet draws parallels between his religious poems and his sermons. A figure who is "slave to fate, chance, kings, and desperate men" is told it is not "mighty and dreadful" in a poem by this writer that tells Death to "be not proud." For 10 points, name this metaphysical poet of the Holy Sonnets.
tossups.answer: John Donne

tossups.question: Though not created by Sun, Microsoft reverse-engineered this language’s interpreter to develop a competing language with a slightly different name. The standard for this language is named for the Ecma International organization. Transpilers like Babel output source code in this language, which is often bundled and minified before use. A dollar sign with parentheses is used to select specific nodes in the DOM (“dom”) in this language’s scripting library (*) jQuery. Native objects in this language print as “[object Object]” ("object object") and can be represented using the JSON (“J-sawn”) format. This language was developed for Netscape Navigator to augment the use of HTML and CSS. Over 95 percent of all websites run, for 10 points, what scripting language which is named similarly to Java?
tossups.answer: JavaScript [or JS; accept JScript; prompt on ECMAScript or ES; do not accept or prompt on "Java"]

bonuses.leadin: The Dickens character Mr. Pickwick nicknames a hypoventilation syndrome associated with this condition. For 10 points each:
answers: obesity [or obese; prompt on overweight]
leptin
brown fat [or brown adipose tissue; or BAT]
parts: Name this condition which is classified as “excessive fat accumulation which presents a risk to health” according to the WHO. People with a BMI over 30 have this condition.
Mice have been shown to exhibit the obese phenotype if they are deficient in this hormone which promotes satiety by acting on lateral receptors in the hypothalamus.

A therapy that is currently being explored to combat obesity involves the stimulation of this heavily energy expending tissue which, unlike its leptin producing counterpart, contains multilocular fat droplets and highly expresses thermogenin.

bonuses.leadin: In a novel, Toto Casals discusses the metaphor of "the yellow of the daisies" in an essay titled for "The [one of these things] I Liked Best". For 10 points each:
answers: films [accept movies, motion pictures, or other equivalents like the plots to films; prompt on plots] (the characters are Molina and Valentin)
Juan Manuel Puig Delledonne
Argentina [or Argentine Republic; or República Argentina]
parts: Name these things. In another novel, five of them are described in detail by a transgender woman to a leftist revolutionary in their shared prison cell.
Kiss of the Spider Woman and Betrayed By Rita Hayworth are both novels by this author, who also wrote about Big Fanny and Juan Carlos Etchepare in Heartbreak Tango.
Puig was an author from this South American country, which was also the birthplace of gaucho literature.

bonuses.leadin: This opera's composer wrote that one character should sound like a "desperate animal on the way to the slaughterhouse" as she lets out a scream. For 10 points each:
answers: Parsifal
Richard Wagner
leitmotifs [or leading motifs; prompt on motifs]
parts: Name this opera. At the end of this opera, the evil sorcerer Klingsor throws a spear at the title character, who uses it to draw a cross.
Parsifal was written by this German composer of the Ring Cycle.

Like Wagner's other operas, Parsifal makes extensive use of these musical ideas that can represent a character, object, or emotion. The most famous of these themes, from Tristan und Isolde, contains the "Tristan chord" and represents desire.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about the short-lived colony of Willoughbyland:
answers: Suriname [or Surinam; or Republic of Suriname; or Republiek Suriname]
English Civil Wars [or First English Revolution; or British Civil Wars; or Wars of the Three Kingdoms; or Second English Civil War; prompt on Great Rebellion; prompt on Civil Wars]
Aphra Behn
parts: The colony, whose democratic experiment was ended by Governor William Byam, was based in this modern-day country in South America. The Dutch gained control of this country in exchange for ceding rights to New York.
The colony was founded by and named for a man fleeing from this conflict. Following this Old World conflict, Oliver Cromwell became Lord Protector.
This author and vigorous enemy of the Whig party based the novella Oroonoko (“or-uh-NO-ko”) on experience gained living in Willoughbyland.

bonuses.leadin: This writer wrote that "the voice of your eyes is deeper than all roses." For 10 points each:
answers: e e cummings [or edward estlin cummings]
rain [accept sun moon stars rain]
"i carry your heart with me" [accept any answer that mentions the speaker is carrying the recipient's heart; prompt on carrying]
parts: Name this American poet of the love poem "somewhere i have never travelled gladly beyond," which ignores proper punctuation and capitalization.

cummings ended that poem by noting that not even this thing has hands as small as his lover. In a repeated four-word phrase from "anyone lived in a pretty how town," this word follows the words "sun moon stars."

Another cummings poem says that this fact is "the root of the root and the bud of the bud." A description is acceptable for this fact, which is followed by the parenthetical statement that the speaker does it in his heart.

bonuses.leadin: Spread Networks dug new mountain tunnels to provide the most direct fiber optic link for firms engaged in this activity. For 10 points each:
answers: high-frequency trading [or HFT; or high-speed trading; accept any answer that involves trading stocks or other financial instruments at high speed; prompt on stock trading]
baseball [accept MLB or major league baseball]
microwave transmission [or microwave radio network; do not accept satellite transmissions]
parts: Identify this specific type of algorithmic economic activity, widely blamed for the Flash Crash of 2010.
Michael Lewis, who wrote about high-frequency trading in Flash Boys, is perhaps best known for Moneyball, a book about an Oakland team in this sport.

Transmissions that use this part of the EM spectrum have replaced slower fiber optic links in high frequency trading. TV broadcasters largely switched from this line-of-sight tech to satellite links in the 1960s.

bonuses.leadin: Most sulfuric acid worldwide is combined with fluorapatite (“flor-APP-uh-tight”) and concentrated to produce single and triple "super" examples of these substances. For 10 points each:
answers: phosphate fertilizers [accept single or triple superphosphate fertilizers]
eutrophication [accept dystrophication, hypertrophication or cultural eutrophication]
dissolved oxygen [or O2]
parts: Name these substances given NPK labels. The gypsum waste from producing these substances must be stored permanently because it off-gasses radon.
Most fertilizer ends up in nearby bodies of water due to agricultural runoff, where its high nutrient load causes this process and produces algal blooms.
The resultant plankton growth depletes this gas from the water, producing hypoxic dead zones which cover thousands of square miles of the Gulf of Mexico.

bonuses.leadin: Wang Anshi instituted short-lived reforms to reduce the amount of rote memorization required in this ordeal. For 10 points each:
answers: Chinese civil service examination [or Chinese imperial examination; accept equivalents like Chinese civil service; or keju]
badges [or plaques; or pins; accept Chairman Mao badges]
Joseon dynasty [or Choson dynasty; or Chosun dynasty]
parts: Identify these tests that might have granted one a position as a provincial official.

From the Ming era, the rank of a civil servant could be identified by the type of bird depicted on one of these objects. During the Cultural Revolution, landowners were prohibited from wearing mass-produced aluminum examples of these items depicting Chairman Mao.
Jo Gwangjo tried to make the Korean version of the imperial examination more practical during this final Korean dynasty.

bonuses.leadin: A piece subtitled for these animals includes the direction to “think of autumn and Tchaikovsky” in its first movement, “The Bog.” For 10 points each:
answers: birds [accept Concerto for Birds and Orchestra]
Finland [or Republic of Finland; or Suomi]
Oliver Messiaen [or Olivier Eugène Prosper Charles Messiaen]
parts: Name these animals that appear in the subtitle of and are heavily featured throughout Cantus Arcticus by Einojuhani Rautavaara (“AY-no-yoo-ha-nee ROUT-ah-var-ah”).
Rautavaara is a composer from this country. Another composer from this country, Jean Sibelius, was inspired by the mythology of the Kalevala to compose The Swan of Tuonela.
Birds inspired a clarinet solo in the “Abyss of the Birds” section of Quartet for the End of Time, which is by this French composer.

bonuses.leadin: Gods are not always immortal. Identify the following deities that have died, for 10 points each:
answers: Osiris
Pan
Dumuzid [accept Tammuz]
parts: This Egyptian god of the dead was decapitated by his brother Set. This god’s consort, Isis, collected the pieces of his body and brought him back to life.
A divine voice supposedly revealed news of this god’s death to a sailor. This god also lost a music contest judged by Tmolus.

The report of Pan’s death may have been a misinterpretation of worshipers proclaiming the death of this Mesopotamian deity. For failing to mourn the death of his wife Inanna, this god of shepherds was dragged into the underworld, where he remains for half of each year.

bonuses.leadin: One play by this author ends with the Shakespearean line “Parting is such sweet sorrow” as a character leaves the stage just before the curtains come crashing down. For 10 points each:
answers: Noël Coward
Blithe Spirit
Percy Shelley
parts: Name this British playwright who wrote about the actor Garry Essendine in Present Laughter, which was originally titled Sweet Sorrow.
The medium Madame Arcati summons the ghost of Charles Condomine's dead wife Elvira in this play by Coward.

Blithe Spirit takes its title from the poem "To a Skylark" by this earlier author, who also wrote the play Prometheus Unbound. The title figure commands, "Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair!" in this author's poem "Ozymandias."

bonuses.leadin: The efficiency of these machines per cycle can be calculated by dividing the mechanical work done by Q-sub-h, the energy received from a heat reservoir. For 10 points each:
answers: engines [or heat engines; or internal-combustion engine]
compression [or adiabatic compression; accept compression ratio]
Albert Einstein
parts: Identify these machines whose ideal form was formulated by Sadi Carnot. A real one of these machines was designed by Rudolf Diesel.

In the Carnot cycle, the heat sink receives the heat rejected by the engine at low temperature during this process. In diesel engines, a ratio named for this stage is usually between 14-to-1 and 22-to-1.
Unlike normal thermodynamic cycle-based refrigerators, the constant-pressure refrigerator designed by this scientist and Leo Szilard requires only a heat source and water, ammonia and butane.

bonuses.leadin: The Akwizgran (“ak-VEEZ-gran”) Discrepancy was created after diplomats at this meeting couldn't resolve who owned a zinc mine, so the area was left blank on the map. For 10 points each:
answers: Congress of Vienna [or Vienna Congress of 1814; prompt on Concert of Europe]
alcohol [or beer; or ale] (the festival is Oktoberfest)
Esperanto
parts: Identify this meeting which was the subject of the doctoral dissertation of Henry Kissinger.

Merchants in the Akwizgran Discrepancy did business smuggling this stuff into Holland. A festival centered around this stuff in Munich began as a celebration of the wedding of the future King Ludwig I in 1810.

Dr. Wilhelm Molly and others hoped to establish the Akwizgran Discrepancy as Amikejo (“ah-mee-KAY-yo”), the first state to speak this language created by L. L. Zamenhof (“ZAH-men-hof”). It's the world's most popular artificial language.

bonuses.leadin: Critics of one portrait of this woman complained that this woman didn't look anything like the portrait, to which the artist, Pablo Picasso, responded, "She will". For 10 points each:
answers: Gertrude Stein (The poster portrait is by Charles Demuth.)
Henri Matisse [or Henri Émile Benoît Matisse]
Le Corbusier [or Charles-Édouard Jeanneret]
parts: Identify this woman who amassed a notable art collection with her brother Leo. A poster portrait of this artist features the word "LOVE" several times.
Stein once owned this artist's Woman with a Hat. This artist of The Joy of Life founded the Fauve movement.
This architect designed the Villa Stein for Gertrude's sister-in-law Sarah. He outlined his views on architecture in his book Towards a New Architecture.

bonuses.leadin: This man sought to prove Wilhelm Wundt wrong by conducting an experiment on himself involving some 2,300 invented nonsense words such as "taz" and "lef." For 10 points each:
answers: Hermann Ebbinghaus
memory
working memory [prompt on primary memory]
parts: Identify this German psychologist who formulated the "forgetting curve."
Ebbinghaus studied this mental faculty, which is divided into short-term and long-term types.

Some scholars draw a distinction between short-term memory and this related form of memory, which has a visuo-spatial component according to a model by Alan Baddeley. Other theories hold that this form of memory can be manipulated, unlike short-term memory.

bonuses.leadin: "Pirate Bill" Johnson burned and looted the steamer Sir Robert Peel in revenge for this event. For 10 points each:
answers: Caroline Affair
Daniel Webster
Aroostook War [or Pork and Beans War]
parts: Name this event where British soldiers crossed into American territory and sent a ship they suspected of aiding William Lyon Mackenzie over Niagara Falls.

This Massachusetts Senator signed a treaty with Baron Ashburton that eased tensions in the wake of the Caroline Affair. This longtime senator formed the "Great Triumvirate" with John C. Calhoun and Henry Clay.
The Webster-Ashburton treaty also settled a boundary dispute between Maine and New Brunswick which had resulted in this conflict, whose only casualties were two Canadian lumberjacks.

bonuses.leadin: In The Merry Wives of Windsor, Falstaff declares, "let the sky rain [these items]… hail kissing-comfits and snow eringoes," a reference to this food's one time use as an aphrodisiac. For 10 points each:
answers: potatoes [do not accept "sweet potato"]
hermit crabs [or Paguroidea; accept coconut crabs or robber crabs; prompt on crabs or crustaceans]
mustard [accept mustard seeds or mustard plant or the Parable of the Mustard Seed]
parts: Identify this food that was long considered dangerous by Europeans. By the 19th century, it had fatefully become a staple food of Ireland.

The largest of these creatures, also the world's largest arthropod, can exert 3,300 newtons of pressure to break open coconuts but are in danger of extinction because their flesh is considered to be an aphrodisiac.
This other aphrodisiac plant grows from an extremely small seed, inspiring Jesus's parable about the Kingdom of Heaven.

bonuses.leadin: In this story, the devil tries to carry an evil mirror up to heaven, shards of which enter Kai's heart and eyes when it splinters. For 10 points each:
answers: "The Snow Queen" [or Snedronningen]
the ugly duckling [or Den grimme ælling; prompt on duckling]
"The Little Match Girl" [or Den Lille Pige med Svovlstikkerne]
parts: Name this tale in which Gerda meets the little robber girl on a journey through Lapland to save Kai from the title character.
In another Hans Christian Andersen tale, this title character becomes trapped in ice during a bitterly cold winter, shortly after which he discovers that he was a swan all along.
The title child of this third Andersen tale meets her grandmother in heaven after freezing to death on New Years' Eve.

bonuses.leadin: A book named after this Biblical patriarch, canonical in the Ethiopian church, describes a rebellion of angelic "Watchers" who impregnate women with evil spirits. For 10 points each:
answers: Enoch [or Chanok; or Henok]
St. Jude [or Judas Thaddaeus or Lebbaeus; prompt on Judas]
Book of Daniel
parts: Name this father of Methuselah. In the Book of Genesis, he is said to have "walked with God, and he was not, for God took him."
This saint's epistle quotes from the non-canonical Book of Enoch, "Behold, the Lord comes with ten thousands of his holy ones." He is venerated as a patron saint of lost causes.
In this book, a "Watcher" commands Nebuchadnezzar to cut down a tree and bind its stump in a dream. This book's namesake prophet is thrown into the lions' den by Darius the Mede.

bonuses.leadin: Alcohols require activation by a Lewis acid to serve as these species and are often replaced by tosylate and nosylate groups, which are very effective examples. For 10 points each:
answers: leaving groups
fluorine [or F]
Frederick Sanger [accept Sanger sequencing]
parts: Name these species which form through cleavage. The first step of an SN1 reaction forms a carbocation and one of these species.
The electronegativity of this lightest halogen makes it a poor leaving group in general and a good leaving group in nucleophilic aromatic substitutions.
This chemist's namesake reagent is attacked by an amino acid in the canonical NAS (“N-A-S”) reaction, which they used to determine the primary sequence of insulin.

bonuses.leadin: In the film In the Heat of the Night, this actor’s character slaps Mr. Endicott in a greenhouse. For 10 points each:
answers: Sidney Poitier [or Sir Sidney Poitier]
Gone with the Wind
police detective [or police or police officer or policeman or policewoman or law officer or police chief] (The film is Fargo.)
parts: Name this Bahamanian-American actor. He became the first African-American to win the Academy Award for Best Actor with his role in Lilies of the Field.

Poitier was the first African-American to win a competitive Oscar since Hattie McDaniel. McDaniel won her Oscar for playing Scarlett O’Hara’s slave in this 1939 film adaptation of a Margaret Mitchell novel.
Sidney Poitier played Virgil Tibbs in In the Heat of the Night, a man with this profession. In another film, a character with this profession finds a man using a woodchipper in the woods.
